Formic acid (HCOOH) is unique among carboxylic acids in reducing Tollens reagent, Fehling solution and acidified KMnO4. The correct reason for this exceptional reducing property is:
options: \text{HCOOH has an aldehyde-like H directly on the carbonyl carbon (H-COOH), allowing it to donate electrons like an aldehyde}

\text{HCOOH is a diprotic acid unlike other monocarboxylic acids}

question: Among the three nitrobenzoic acid isomers, Ka values are: o-NO2 (35.0×10-5) > p-NO2 (6.0×10-5) ≈ m-NO2 (32.0×10-5). The ortho isomer is the strongest acid despite -NO2 being a meta-director. The correct explanation for ortho being strongest is:
options: \text{Ortho -NO}_2\text{ exerts both -I and -M effects AND the ortho effect (steric inhibition of resonance of -COOH with ring reduces its donation, increasing acidity)}
\text{The ortho isomer has a lower pKa due to intramolecular H-bonding with -COOH}
answer: \text{Ortho -NO}_2\text{ exerts both -I and -M effects AND the ortho effect (steric inhibition of resonance of -COOH with ring reduces its donation, increasing acidity)}
tip: Ortho rule: any substituent at ortho position tends to make benzoic acid stronger than its para counterpart — steric strain forces -COOH out of the ring plane, disrupting its resonance and making the carboxylate more stable on ionisation.

Peracetic acid (CH3COOOH) is a weaker acid than acetic acid, even though it has an additional electronegative -OOH group. The correct reason is:
options: \text{Acetate ion (CH}_3\text{COO}^-\text{) is resonance-stabilised; peroxyacetate ion is not as well-stabilised due to lone pair repulsion between adjacent oxygens}
\text{Peracetic acid has higher molecular weight reducing acidity}
\text{The O-O bond in peracetic acid makes it less polar}
\text{Peracetic acid forms stronger intramolecular H-bonds reducing ionisation}
answer: \text{Acetate ion (CH}_3\text{COO}^-\text{) is resonance-stabilised; peroxyacetate ion is not as well-stabilised due to lone pair repulsion between adjacent oxygens}
tip: More electronegative substituent doesn't always mean stronger acid — the stability of the conjugate base matters. Here, O-O lone pair repulsion in peroxyacetate actually destabilises it, outweighing the inductive effect of -OOH.
